articles.headline: Rice Concedes Error on Libya; G.O.P. Digs In
articles.snippet: Three Senate Republicans signaled that they would still oppose Susan E. Rice, the ambassador to the United Nations, if she is nominated for secretary of state.
articles.abstract: Three Senate Republicans signaled that they would still oppose Susan E. Rice, the ambassador to the United Nations, if she is nominated for secretary of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Susan E. Rice may have hoped that paying a conciliatory call on three hostile Senate Republicans on Tuesday would smooth over a festering dispute about the deadly attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, and clear a roadblock to her nomination as secretary of state.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Apple Fires a Manager Over Its Misfire on Maps
articles.snippet: Apple continues to clean house after it stumbled badly with its mobile mapping service, firing a manager who oversaw it. Eddy Cue, the senior vice president for Internet software and services at Apple, fired the manager, Richard Williamson, accord...
articles.abstract: Apple continues to clean house after it stumbled badly with its mobile mapping service, firing a manager who oversaw it. Eddy Cue, the senior vice president for Internet software and services at Apple, fired the manager, Richard Williamson, according to two people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Combating Inequality May Require Broader Tax
articles.snippet: While raising taxes on the rich is a start, and may help us dig out of our immediate fiscal hole, it is unlikely to be enough to address our long-term needs.
articles.abstract: While raising taxes on the rich is a start, and may help us dig out of our immediate fiscal hole, it is unlikely to be enough to address our long-term needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rarely have we experienced such a confluence of arguments in favor of raising taxes on the rich. After a hard-won re-election fought mainly over taxes and spending, President Obama arguably has a mandate from voters to tap the wealthy to address our budget woes.

articles.headline: A Struggling CNN Worldwide Is Said to Be Drawn to Jeffrey Zucker
articles.snippet: If he is named, Jeffrey Zucker, the former chief executive of NBCUniversal, is likely to face an identity crisis at a channel with many competing visions.
articles.abstract: If he is named, Jeffrey Zucker, the former chief executive of NBCUniversal, is likely to face an identity crisis at a channel with many competing visions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the days to come, when Time Warner appoints a new leader of CNN Worldwide for the first time in a decade, that person will face an identity crisis unlike any other in corporate America.

articles.headline: With a Billion Birthdays on File, Facebook Adds a Gift Store
articles.snippet: Facebook has started an online gift service, hoping that the moneymaking potential of social gift giving will please its Wall Street investors.
articles.abstract: Facebook has started an online gift service, hoping that the moneymaking potential of social gift giving will please its Wall Street investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook is already privy to its users’ e-mail addresses, wedding pictures and political beliefs. Now the company is nudging them to share a bit more: credit card numbers and offline addresses.

articles.headline: Buybacks Expected to Increase
articles.snippet: A survey suggested that companies were likely to buy more of their own shares after this year because taxes on those gains were expected to grow less than a proposed tax increase on dividends.
articles.abstract: A survey suggested that companies were likely to buy more of their own shares after this year because taxes on those gains were expected to grow less than a proposed tax increase on dividends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors are bracing for companies to ramp up purchases of their own shares in response to expected tax changes in the new year, despite growing criticism of buybacks.

articles.headline: Two Families Show an Uneven Rise in Consumer Confidence
articles.snippet: American consumer confidence rose to the highest level in five years in November, according to preliminary figures, but two families’ holiday shopping illustrates how regional differences persist.
articles.abstract: American consumer confidence rose to the highest level in five years in November, according to preliminary figures, but two families’ holiday shopping illustrates how regional differences persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angelina Sam couldn’t afford to celebrate Christmas last year, serving peanut butter, soup and rice for the holiday meal. And she didn’t buy gifts for her husband or 2-year-old son.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford, Christina Capecchi and Christopher Maag

articles.headline: California Finds Economic Gloom Starting to Lift
articles.snippet: After nearly five years of brutal economic decline, government retrenchment and a widespread loss of confidence in its future, California is showing the first signs of a rebound.
articles.abstract: After nearly five years of brutal economic decline, government retrenchment and a widespread loss of confidence in its future, California is showing the first signs of a rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After nearly five years of brutal economic decline, government retrenchment and a widespread loss of confidence in its future, California is showing the first signs of a rebound. There is evidence of job growth, economic stability, a resurgent housing market and rising spirits in a state that was among the worst hit by the recession.

articles.headline: Sunni Leaders Gaining Clout in Mideast
articles.snippet: The United States is left somewhat wary about the rising Sunni Muslim alliance of Egypt, Qatar and Turkey and its potential for anti-Western sentiment.
articles.abstract: The United States is left somewhat wary about the rising Sunni Muslim alliance of Egypt, Qatar and Turkey and its potential for anti-Western sentiment.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — For years, the United States and its Middle East allies were challenged by the rising might of the so-called Shiite crescent, a political and ideological alliance backed by Iran that linked regional actors deeply hostile to Israel and the West.

articles.headline: Now Touring, the Debt Duo, Simpson-Bowles
articles.snippet: Erskine B. Bowles, President Bill Clinton’s former chief of staff, and former Republican Senator Alan K. Simpson have been discussing budgets and baselines in an improbable buddy act.
articles.abstract: Erskine B. Bowles, President Bill Clinton’s former chief of staff, and former Republican Senator Alan K. Simpson have been discussing budgets and baselines in an improbable buddy act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Theirs is an improbable buddy act that is making for unlikely entertainment from campuses to corporations on a most serious subject: the federal debt. The proof of their appeal: some business groups pay them $40,000 each per appearance. Really. To discuss budgets and baselines.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Weighs Suit Against SAC Capital
articles.snippet: SAC Capital Advisors told investors it had received a so-called Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission, an indication the agency was considering an enforcement action against the hedge fund.
articles.abstract: SAC Capital Advisors told investors it had received a so-called Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission, an indication the agency was considering an enforcement action against the hedge fund.
